- i keep chips at home, so their insulting policy of charging you $0.25 for a sandwich bag of 10-15 chips doesn't impact me. negative stars for the times i've run out at home and pay for them anyways.
- the pico de gallo/salsa fresca is underwhelming and detracts from the better food
- no salsa bar/no unlimited [or reasonable defaults of] salsa is insulting
- the hot sauce (sauce, not salsa) is awesome - 5/5 stars.

tangental:
i like the hot sauce. so much so that i would buy a half pint every time i go there. why don't i? although you can get 1/2 pints or pints of salsa, guacamole, rice, and beans: hot sauce is not on the menu. occasionally someone on staff has been smart enough to realize that selling a few pennies worth of hot sauce for more than a hundred pennies is good business sense. perhaps they are less financially driven and just have the good sense that bickering over some pureed tomato and pepper isn't good customer service. i dream that one day the wisdom clicks and the rest of the staff follow suit. at this point, i ask to buy half pint just to see what happens.

which leads me to the day manager (owner?). the profitable hot sauce logic escapes & asking her to contemplate it angers her. she berates the staff for problems outside of their control (see above re: lines/space issues). thankfully, she doesn't seem to work there past about 5pm or on weekends.

outside of the mission, this is one of the better taquerias i've been to; even with the insanity of denying someone who wants to pay an order of magnitude above what the product costs to make. 

so if you're reading this, Taqueria Dos Amigos, please put 'hot sauce half pint/pint' pricing on your menu board and we'll pretend it was always that way.

until then, you know i'm just going to keep asking every time i come.
author: bill f.

description:
can't figure out the 3 stars and below reviews.

if you are looking for something different, try their specials:
1) bulgogi burrito (korean bbq with onion & bell pepper) - best as tacos
2) pulled pork and cole slaw
3) meditteranean with black bean (this one is my personal fave and also good for vegetarians!)

i'll be back again and again for #3, i can't get enough of it!
author: Josie M.

description: Convenience is really what brings me here as I work literally 500 feet from this place.  So when I'm craving a burrito for lunch this is my place!  I usually order the vegetarian baby burrito with half black beans and half refried beans on a wheat wrap.  It's tasty, always hits the spot, not over priced but nothing spectacular on taste.  I like the complimentary chips and salsa.  I should also point out they have several mini tables set up for outdoor seating--always an added benefit in my book!
author: Jennifer B.

description: Got the vegetable burrito stuffed with freshly sauteed zucchini, peppers, cauliflower and broccoli. Yum!
author: Donna W.

description: I feel a little crappy giving this place 2 stars, but as the rating system says, "meh, I've experienced better." I feel crappy because the staff is courteous and the place is clean -- plus it's the only burrito place besides Urban Taqueria that's located this side of the Gift Center. I agree with Krist M. -- the food is unexciting and tastes out of a can. Definitely better than a frozen burrito, but not up to snuff when compared to other taquerias in SF.
author: Dan E.

description:
The past month marked the grand opening of Dos Amigos Taqueria just around the corner from my building.  This was a heavily anticipated opening, as tacos are right in my lunchtime wheelhouse, and the bare rudeness of my current options leads me to fantasize over any newcomers to the scene.

Unfortunately, Dos Amigos underwhelmed in nearly every regard.  Let's start with pricing:

At $2.85 per taco, this is the most expensive taco option within my lunch radius and perhaps within all of San Francisco proper.  The pricing scheme leaves the consumer in stuck between two less-than-ideal lunching nodes:  Do I go for a reasonably-priced yet less-than-fulfilling deuce-taco combo?  Or do I buy the third, ensuring fullness (likely even stuffedness), but launching the lunch price tag into the $9 range pre-drink?  Neither option is a catastrophe, yet neither is anywhere near ideal.

Tortillas:  Plus points for white corn, minus points for steaming instead of quick frying.  A steamed taco tortilla is a recipe for a mess -- the tortilla must act as a meat hammock of sorts, and steaming lends to the burstability of this support system.  Steam my flour tortillas for my burritos, but do NOT steam my tacotillas.

Meat contents: The options were standard (Carne Asada, Chicken, and Al Pastor) -- but the meats were sitting in BINS getting COLD.  Taco meat should come straight off the frying surface and into the taco without passing GO or collecting $200.

Cheese:  I had to shout in order to keep cheese off of my taco.  They were forcibly placing cheese on tacos.  This is an offense against all tacos everywhere.

Salsas: Lacked punch AND pizazz.  Did not lack water.  Soaked through the tortillas almost instantaneously.  The resulting meal was more like a taco salad that I would NEVER have ordered in the first place.

I thought I was about to make Dos new Amigos.   What a bummer.
author: Ben A.

description: If you order the right stuff here it's pretty darn good. I love the superburrito with black beans and pollo verde. Vegetarian burrito is also solid. Perfectly respectable chicken nachos, and they're generous with the meat. However there are a few cons: basically no indoor seating, tough parking, and a certain lack of authenticity. No aguas frescas, lousy horchata. Still, overall I give it a thumbs-up.
author: Dave S.

description: Had the steak burrito, very legit in my opinion. Nothing super special but above average. Still can't figure out how/why Mexican places in SOMA can charge $8 a burrito though.
author: Matt Z.

description: It's lunchtime Sunday, and I hadn't eaten for a good 24 hours (pretty much since a late breakfast Saturday), so maybe that's some context for why my carnitas tacos hit the spot.  But they did.   Eat 'em hot.  (They lost a little in the transportation to work, where I am now, having just wolfed my tacos.  But they were pretty tasty.)
author: Laurel B.

description: Had dinner here the other night with my friend. Though there was only one worker on staff, he handed out pretty large portions and really hustled in the back. The steak could have been a little bit more juicy and flavorful. But, this place sure beats many of the Mexican places I've been to in the city.
author: Jj H.

description: the baby burritos are decent - I just got a chile relleno it was pretty much the worst one I have ever had.
author: shawn p.

description:
Fairly average Taqueria but its located in SoMa, one of the few that is. 
Its clean though, thats for sure.
The highlight is that they'll do a chocolate mole super burrito which I haven't found anywheres else, but unfortunately you need to be here when it opens to get fresh food on the weekends, or else the food is stagnant.  Maybe weekdays are higher turnover leading to fresher food, I don't know, but be careful on the weekends.
author: Johan E.

description: In a neighborhood seriously lacking solid, quick, and cheap lunch spots, "The Two Friends" as it has become known, is among the best for an easy lunch during the week. It is fast, the meat is pretty quality, but best of all the burrito technicians here have perfected the art of the "The Spread". Ya know when you get a burrito and the ingredients are all unevenly distributed and you end up with a 2 inch pocket of sour cream? Yeah? You hate that? Me too. At The Two Friends, you may notice a quick manuever - often undetectable to the human eye - in which they evenly distibute the ingredients into even bands through out the delicious cylinder. If they don't already teach that at Burrito College, they should. 4 stars for sucking less than the other places around my office.
author: Heavy B.

description: Dos Amigos is good.  Right next to REI on Brannan.  Try the Carne Asada.  The service is quick, friendly and the food is good!
author: John B.

description: We were in the area and found ourselves super hungry at 1:30.  Driving along, we spotted this taqueria and decided to give it a try since there weren't many options in the area.  Since dinner was at 6:30, we didn't want a huge meal.  I ordered a "super" taco with carnitas and my hunger was baaaaaarely satisfied.  The taco tasted fine, but for $4.45 I was expecting a little bit more food.  There are tables outside to eat which is great if it's not freezing cold, but there are only 2 tables in the place itself.  Like those "restaurants" at SFO, go here to get overpriced food since you otherewise don't have much choice!!
author: Tim L.

description: Dos Amigos puts out good food. The decor shouldnt even be a thought in your head since its a small place that is clearly set up for you to take your burrito on the go.  I got a carne asada burrito that was damb good. I live down the street and a quality burrito in this area is going to be well received by the neighborhood.
author: Michael G.

description: First of all, those 5 tables you see outside when you go by REI are the entire seating area. Then the pricing is clearly for the Exhibition Center/Gift Mart (i.e out of town) crowd. The food is very average. My gripe with my taco was they take a hamburger-type take out box, stuff some tortillas into the bottom, and then pile on the toppings (meaning mainly lots of lettuce), so there is no possible way to pick up the taco. It is like a taco salad without the deep fried goodness.
author: Amy E.

description: I love this place. It's close to my work and I am a Mexican food fan. Today I tried their cactus burrito and i'll get it again. Generally I eat their vegetarian burrito with black beans and i've never been disapointed. They are large burritos and they taste good. I take them back to work and eat em, so I don't mind that they only have a few tables outside... all in all, I say they hit the spot and wouldn't ask them to change a thing
author: Bret C.

description: ok im sorry this might be an ok taqueria by SF standards...but the quality is very baddd....the pinto beans are white (clearly out of a can) as are their refried beans...their chips are store bought lacking the crispiness of freshly made ones....their meats are over seasoned/marinated (the burrito drips with grease when you get it) and everything is overpriced for what you get....the Urban Taqueria up the street near Trader Joe's is a lot more savory and cheap! I honestly don't understand why this place is always busy...
author: Sancho P.

description:
Dos Amigos fails to impress yet again. Just finished up my super carne asada burrito and though I'm about to go into a food coma, I find myself wishing I would've gone to Dos Pinas instead, or better yet, Luna. The reason I even bother giving it a chance is due to the convenience of the location. What's not to like? Alright, let's get started.

The service is piss poor. Somebody please teach these ladies how to smile. A lesson in paying attention would also help. On both occasions I've been here, they've screwed up our order. This should be pretty elementary stuff, really. I mean, I'm there the whole time, picking out beans as they are making my food. But as you're getting excited about that sour cream and guac getting thrown into the mix, your super burrito is suddenly demoted to a regular and rolled up without the crucial aforementioned ingredients. After correcting an order, whomever screwed up will look at you and infallibly go "Oh, you didn't order that."

Service aside, let's talk about the food, which is mediocre at best. As someone already mentioned, this is a lazy taqueria where everything is in bins from which you make your picks, rather than freshly cooked up on the stove. This doesn't necessarily have to be so bad, but the least you could expect is that the binned meats are of good quality. Let's just say I had to pick out two pieces of unchewable fat out of today's carne asada burrito. What's worse, the super nachos were carelessly thrown together and shoved into a microwave to be transformed into a nasty, soggy mess. If you care at all about your nachos, the preceding sentence hopefully already made you move on to another lunch option.
author: Patrick M.

description: I discovered this place a few weeks ago, located in the designer district snuggled against the Concourse building. It is the only mexican taqueria around the area, and as far as I know, in eastern SOMA, and it truly is a gem. You get about 10 different choices of meats on your burrito, including chicken mole, carne asada, spicy pulled chicken, etc. I recommend the baby burrito, which has all of the ingredients of the super burrito, but is, ta da, smaller (and about $2 less!) Still a filling size and served with sour cream, guacamole, rice, beans, and meat. I am hooked to this food, and travel out of my way to get here when I am craving Mexican. This review is all about the food, because there are some inconveniences, such as no real dining area and no bathroom ( you have to go through security next door to pee! )
author: T W.

description:
we went to this place earlier this week for a lunch break from shopping at jewelrymart for possible wedding jewelry. i got a vegetarian taco (black beans, rice, salsa, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, lettuce...). it was big and yummy, but messy! my sister ordered a chicken burrito and it was pretty messy as well and dripped all over, but she liked it! we also ordered nachos to share, no meat. yes, they were microwaved but they were really good! my sister also got a drink and it was just under $20...didnt seem too expensive to me.

so i had no problems at all with the food, but women working the counter were completely unfriendly, which is why i am lowering my stars. they didnt seem to enjoy being there and were behind the counter texting while we were deciding what we wanted. not that its really that bad, but....i dont know, it just rubbed me the wrong way.  and they have like no seating inside, and all the trash cans were full.

i would go back if i was in the area!
author: jenny s.

description:
This place has never had good food.  The service has never been good.  I always leave feeling I was ripped off.  I think the cashiers charge different prices.  I know this because I have paid different prices for the same items at different times.
But this is what I'm most pissed about.  A BEE BEING served in my vegie quesedilla.  When I brought the bee invested product back to them, they gave me a hard time.  DO NOT EAT HERE.  Walk to the mission and get some real food.  This place sucks.
author: Dominic P.

description:
Stopped here after an event at the Concourse.
$10 and some change got me a burrito with a soda.
Not bad, nothing special.
Ate at the table's on the sidewalk.
Was hoping for more room inside to eat but it is pretty cramped.
author: Anthony A.

description: The taco here was quite all right! Their burritos even better! And they actually make mole pollo which you can throw in your burrito! It's not mole negro, it's a more traditional typical red/brown mole sauce. Not spicy. Just very tasty and delicious! I had the super burrito with the mole pollo (that's chicken) with the whole works, sour cream, salsa, guacamole, etc. SO BIG! So scrumptious! So warm! I devoured the whole thing in one sitting. The location is pretty random. I think they get a lot of customers from the Hispanic locals and from folks who shop at either REI or the Jewelry Gift Center because this little taco joint is situated smack in between these big buildings. Works out great if you want a good bite but don't want to deal with the hassle of parking elsewhere or walking far to find a place to eat. I had a bit of the diced chicken which they allowed me to try before choosing my meat for my super burrito. It was tasty and tender! The carne asada was smoky and well-cooked (I usually like them a bit tender or pink) but the carne asada was minced well so it would blend very well with the burrito. Price was fair for what you're getting. Toodle a loo!  :)
author: Pamela L.

description: This place is not bad.  Nice and close, prices about average for the area and they're fast.  Would prolly recommend the green pork and the shrimp quesadilla is tasty.
author: Monkey G.

description: this place is in the middle of nowhere in soma, but totally worth the 15 min walk from my office!  The food is solid and far superior to Victor's (the other taqueria in the area with that "GUAPO" lady).
author: Stan K.

description: mmmmm this place is super good!  they have bul go gi burritos, mediterranean burritos, and of course the regular types.    the chips and salsa are great too!   burritos are way too big for me to finish (which is awesome).
author: thien t.

description: There's not anywhere else for Mexican food around but it is still better to do without rather than eat here. Raggedy, wet, and overpriced. The Costco chips repackaged in sandwich bags with small condiment container of salsa were insult to injury.
author: Arptro H.
